revision.comment: Adding local [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Unmanned space exploration vehicle", overriding Wikidata description "unmanned robotic spacecraft that does not orbit the Earth, but, instead, explores further into outer space" ([[Wikipedia:Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Unmanned space exploration vehicle}} [[File:Pioneer H.JPG|300px|thumb|Abandoned 1974 probe, [[Pioneer H]], on display in the [[National Air and Space Museum]]]] [[File:What's Up in the Solar System, active space probes 2019-07.png|thumb|450px|Diagram of extant Solar System missions (see Reference{{cite web |url=http://www.planetary.org/multimedia/space-images/charts/whats-up-in-the-solar-system-frohn.html |title=What's Up in the Solar System diagram by Olaf Frohn |publisher=[[The Planetary Society]]}} for most recent version)]] A '''space probe''' is a [[robotic spacecraft]] that does not [[Earth orbit|orbit]] [[Earth]], but instead, explores further into [[outer space]].{{cite web |url=http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/media/space-probes/ |title=Space Probes |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |work=National Geographic Education|date=2011-09-30 }} A space probe may approach the [[Moon]]; travel through [[interplanetary space]]; [[planetary flyby|flyby]], [[orbit]], or [[landing|land]] on other [[planetary system|planetary]] [[astronomical object|bodies]]; or enter [[interstellar space]]. The [[space agencies]] of the [[Soviet space program|USSR]] (now [[Russian Federal Space Agency|Russia]] and [[National Space Agency of Ukraine|Ukraine]]), the [[NASA|United States]], the [[European Space Agency|European Union]], [[Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency|Japan]], [[China National Space Administration|China]], [[Indian Space Research Organisation|India]], and [[SpaceIL|Israel]] have collectively launched probes to several [[planet]]s and [[moons]] of the [[Solar System]], as well as to a number of [[asteroid]]s and [[comet]]s. Approximately 15 missions are currently operational.{{cite web |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/emily-lakdawalla/2015/12311322-planetary-exploration-timelines.html |title=Planetary Exploration Timelines: A Look Ahead to 2016 |publisher=[[The Planetary Society]]}} {{further|List of active Solar System probes}} == Interplanetary trajectories == Once a probe has left the vicinity of Earth, its trajectory will likely take it along an [[Heliocentric orbit|orbit around the]] [[Sun]] similar to the Earth's orbit. To reach another planet, the simplest practical method is a [[Hohmann transfer orbit]]. More complex techniques, such as [[gravitational slingshot]]s, can be more fuel-efficient, though they may require the probe to spend more time in transit. Some high [[Delta-V]] missions (such as those with high [[Orbital inclination change|inclination changes]]) can only be performed, within the limits of modern propulsion, using gravitational slingshots. A technique using very little propulsion, but requiring a considerable amount of time, is to follow a trajectory on the [[Interplanetary Transport Network]].{{cite web|url=http://pr.caltech.edu/periodicals/EandS/articles/LXV4/exit.html|title=E&S+|work=E&S+}} == Some notable probes == File:Lunokhod-1 in Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics 01.jpg|The [[Lunokhod 1]] uncrewed rover on the surface of [[Moon]], displayed in Memorial Museum of Cosmonautics. File:PIA16239 High-Resolution Self-Portrait by Curiosity Rover Arm Camera.jpg|The [[Curiosity (rover)|''Curiosity'']] rover on the surface of [[Mars]]. File:Rosetta and Philae at comet (11206660686).jpg|The [[Rosetta (spacecraft)|''Rosetta'']] orbiter and [[Philae (spacecraft)|''Philae'']] lander nearing comet [[67P/Churyumov–Gerasimenko|67P]]. File:Voyager_spacecraft.jpg|''[[Voyager 2]]'' in [[interplanetary space]]. File:Art1_deepimpact.jpg|Artist's concept of [[Deep Impact (spacecraft)|''Deep Impact'']] prior to its planned collision with comet [[Tempel 1]]. ===[[Luna 9]]=== First man-made object to [[soft landing (rocketry)|soft land]] on the Moon, or any other extra terrestrial surface.{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1966-006A|title=NASA – NSSDCA – Spacecraft – Details|publisher=}} ===[[Luna 3]]=== First mission to photograph the far side of the Moon, launched in 1959. ===[[Luna 16]]=== First robotic [[sample return]] probe from the Moon. ===[[Lunokhod 1]]=== First rover on Moon. It was sent to the Moon on November 10, 1970. ===[[Mariner 10]]=== First probe to Mercury. ===[[Venera 4]]=== First successful in-place analysis of another planet. It may have also been the first space probe to impact the surface of another planet, although it is unclear whether it reached Venus' surface.{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1967-058A|title=NASA – NSSDCA – Spacecraft – Details|publisher=}} Launched in 1967. ===Venera 7=== The [[Venera 7]] probe was the first spacecraft to successfully soft [[Landings on other planets|land on another planet]] (Venus) and to transmit data from there back to [[Earth]]. ===Mariner 9=== Upon its arrival at Mars on November 13, 1971, [[Mariner 9]] became the first space probe to maintain orbit around another planet.http://marsprogram.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/past/mariner8-9.html {{-}} [[Image:Huygens surface color.jpg|thumb|The ''[[Huygens probe|Huygens]]'' landing site on [[Titan (moon)|Titan]]]] ===[[Mars 3]]=== First soft landing on [[Mars]] (December 2, 1971[https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraft/display.action?id=1971-049F Mars 3 Lander]. NASA Space Science Data Coordination. NASA) The lander began transmitting to the Mars 3 orbiter 90 seconds after landing. After 20 seconds, transmission stopped for unknown reasons. ===[[Sojourner (rover)|Sojourner]]=== First successful rover on [[Mars]].[[Sojourner (rover)]] ===''Spirit'' and ''Opportunity''=== The [[Mars Exploration Rover]]s, ''[[Spirit rover|Spirit]]'' and ''[[Opportunity rover|Opportunity]]'' landed on Mars to explore the Martian surface and [[geology]], and searched for clues to past water activity on Mars. They were each launched in 2003 and landed in 2004. Communication with ''Spirit'' stopped on sol 2210 (March 22, 2010).[http://marsrovers.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/status_spiritAll.html#sol2397 September 30 – October 05, 2010 Spirit Remains Silent at Troy] NASA. 2010-10-05.A.J.S. Rayl [http://www.planetary.org/news/2010/1130_Mars_Exploration_Rovers_Update_Mission.html Mars Exploration Rovers Update] ''[[Planetary Society]]'' 30 November 2010 JPL continued to attempt to regain contact until May 24, 2011, when NASA announced that efforts to communicate with the unresponsive rover had ended.{{cite web|last=Webster |first=Guy |title=NASA's Spirit Rover Completes Mission on Mars |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mer/news/mer20110525.html|date=25 May 2011 |publisher=[[NASA]] |accessdate=2011-10-12 }}{{cite web|title=NASA Concludes Attempts to Contact Mars Rover Spirit|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.cfm?release=2011-156&cid=release_2011-156|publisher=NASA|accessdate=25 May 2011}}{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=NASA to Abandon Mars Spirit Rover |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/25/science/space/25rover.html |date=May 24, 2011|work=New York Times}} ''Opportunity'' arrived at [[Endeavour crater]] on 9 August 2011, at a landmark called ''Spirit Point'' named after [[Spirit rover|its rover twin]], after traversing {{convert|13|miles}} from [[Victoria crater]], over a three-year period.[http://marsrovers.jpl.nasa.gov/newsroom/pressreleases/20110810a.html NASA Mars Rover Arrives at New Site on Martian Surface] ''Jet Propulsion Laboratory'', 10 August 2011. After a planet wide dust storm in June 2018, the final communication was received on June 10, 2018, and ''Opportunity'' was declared dead on February 13, 2019. The rover lasted for almost fifteen years on Mars — although the rover was intended to last only three months.{{cite web |last1=Brown |first1=Dwayne |last2=Wendel |first2=JoAnna |title=NASA's Record-Setting Opportunity Rover Mission on Mars Comes to End |url=https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasas-record-setting-opportunity-rover-mission-on-mars-comes-to-end/ |website=NASA |accessdate=10 April 2019|date=2019-02-13 }} ===[[Halley Armada]]=== The first dedicated missions to a comet; in this case, to [[Halley's Comet]] during its 1985–86 journey through the inner Solar System. It was also the first massive international coordination of space probes on an interplanetary mission, with probes specifically launched by the Soviet (now Russian) Space Agency, European Space Agency, and Japan's ISAS (now integrated with NASA to JAXA). ====[[International Cometary Explorer|ICE]]==== Originally a solar observatory in the International Sun-Earth Explorer series, it was sent into solar orbit to make the first close observations of a comet, [[21P/Giacobini–Zinner|Comet Giacobini–Zinner]], in 1985 as a prelude to studies of Halley's Comet. ====[[Vega program|Vega]]==== Two Russian/French spacecraft. They dropped landers and balloons (first weather balloons deployed on another planet) at Venus before their rendezvous with Halley's Comet. ====[[Sakigake]]==== This Japanese probe was the first non-US, non-Soviet interplanetary probe.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} ====[[Suisei (probe)|Suisei]]==== A second Japanese probe, it made ultraviolet wavelength observations of the comet.{{Clarify|date=February 2015}} ====[[Giotto mission|Giotto]]==== The first space probe to penetrate a comet's [[Coma (cometary)|coma]] and take close-up images of its nucleus. ===[[Genesis (spacecraft)|Genesis]]=== First [[solar wind]] sample return probe from sun-earth L1.{{cite web |url=http://genesismission.jpl.nasa.gov |title=Genesis – Search for Origins |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=July 13, 2016}} ===[[Stardust (spacecraft)|Stardust]]=== First sample return probe from a comet tail. ===[[NEAR Shoemaker]]=== First probe to land on an asteroid. ===[[Hayabusa]]=== First sample return probe to launch from an [[asteroid]]. ===Rosetta=== The [[Rosetta space probe]] flew by two asteroids and made a rendezvous and orbited [[comet]] [[67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko]] in November 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2010/04/100426113112.htm|title="Where Comets Emit Dust: Scientists Identify the Active Regions on the Surface of Comets" – ScienceDaily (Apr. 29, 2010)|work=sciencedaily.com}} ===[[Pioneer 10]]=== Launched 1972. First probe to Jupiter. Radio communications were lost with Pioneer 10 on January 23, 2003, because of the loss of electric power for its radio transmitter, with the probe at a distance of 12 billion kilometers (80 AU) from Earth. ===[[Pioneer 11]]=== First probe to fly by Saturn. (Communications were later lost due to power constraints and vast distance.) ===[[Voyager 1]]=== [[File:Voyager 1's view of Solar System (artist's impression).jpg|thumb|''[[Voyager 1]]'''s view of Solar System (artist's impression).{{cite web|title=Voyager 1's view of Solar System (artist's impression)|url=https://www.spacetelescope.org/images/opo1701a/|website=www.spacetelescope.org|accessdate=12 January 2017}}]] ''[[Voyager 1]]'' is a 733-kilogram probe launched September 5, 1977. It visited [[Jupiter]] and [[Saturn]] and was the first probe to provide detailed images of the moons of these planets. ''Voyager 1'' is the farthest human-made object from [[Earth]], traveling away from both the Earth and the [[Sun]] at a relatively faster speed than any other probe.{{cite web|title=NASA Voyager 1 Encounters New Region in Deep Space|url=http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/news/voyager_1_new_region.html|publisher=NASA}} As of September 12, 2013, ''Voyager 1'' is about 12 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] miles (19 billion kilometers) from the Sun.{{cite web|url=http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/|title=Voyager – The Interstellar Mission|author=JPL.NASA.GOV|work=nasa.gov}} On August 25, 2012, ''Voyager 1'' became the first human made object to enter interstellar space.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/voyager/voyager20130912.html#.Ukixi4brzhg|title=NASA Spacecraft Embarks on Historic Journey Into Interstellar Space|work=NASA|date=2015-05-05}} ''Voyager 1'' has not had a functioning plasma sensor since 1980, but a solar flare in 2012 allowed scientists from NASA to measure vibrations of the plasma surrounding the craft. The vibrations allowed scientists to measure the plasma to be much denser than measurements taken in the far layers of our [[heliosphere]], thus concluding the craft had broken beyond the [[Heliopause (astronomy)|heliopause]]. === [[Voyager 2]] === Voyager 2 was launched by NASA on August 20, 1977. The probe's primary mission was to visit the [[Ice giant|ice giants]], [[Uranus]] and [[Neptune]], which it completed on October 2, 1989. It is currently the only probe to have visited the ice giants. It is the fourth of five spacecraft to have left the solar system. It has been operational for 41 years and 2 months as of October 20, 2018. ===[[Cassini–Huygens]]=== Cassini–Huygens was a 5,712-kg (12,593-lb) space probe designed to study gas giant [[Saturn]], along with its ringed system and moons. The NASA probe was launched with ESA lander [[Huygens (spacecraft)|Huygens]] on October 1, 1997 from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 40|Cape Canaveral]]. The Cassini probe entered Saturn orbit on July 1, 2004, and Huygens landed on [[Titan (moon)|Titan]], Saturn's largest moon, on January 14, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://sci.esa.int/cassini-huygens/34956-huygens-probe-separation/|title=Huygens Probe Separation and Coast Phase|publisher=}} On September 15, 2017, the probe was de-orbited and burned up in Saturn's atmosphere, after almost 20 years in space. ===[[New Horizons]]=== First probe to be launched to Pluto. Launched on January 19, 2006, it flew by the Pluto–Charon system on July 14, 2015.{{cite web |last1=Brown |first1=Dwayne |last2=Buckley |first2=Michael |last3=Stothoff |first3=Maria |title=January 15, 2015 Release 15-011 – NASA's New Horizons Spacecraft Begins First Stages of Pluto Encounter |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2015/january/nasa-s-new-horizons-spacecraft-begins-first-stages-of-pluto-encounter |date=15 January 2015 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=15 January 2015 }} ===[[Dawn (spacecraft)|Dawn]]=== First spacecraft to visit and orbit a [[protoplanet]] ([[4 Vesta]]), entering orbit on July 16, 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.space.com/17119-nasa-dawn-asteroid-spacecraft-vesta.html |title=NASA's Dawn Spacecraft Hits Snag on Trip to 2 Asteroids |publisher=Space.com |date=August 15, 2012 |accessdate=August 27, 2012}}{{cite web |title=Dawn Gets Extra Time to Explore Vesta |publisher=[[NASA]] |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?release=2012-107 |date=April 18, 2012 |accessdate=April 24, 2012 }} Entered orbit around dwarf planet [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] in early 2015. Currently orbiting Ceres as of February 2017. ===[[Juno (spacecraft)|Juno]]=== First probe to Jupiter without [[atomic battery|atomic batteries]],{{cite web |title=NASA's Juno Mission to Jupiter to Be Farthest Solar-Powered Trip |url=http://www.space.com/12541-juno-jupiter-mission-solar-panels-power.html |accessdate=October 2, 2015}} launched August 8, 2011. ===[[Chang'e 2]]=== [[Chang'e 2]] was deployed to orbit the Moon, visit Sun–Earth L2 [[Lagrangian point]], and make a flyby of asteroid [[4179 Toutatis]].{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} ===Beyond the Solar System=== Along with ''[[Pioneer 10]]'', ''[[Pioneer 11]]'', and its sister space probe ''[[Voyager 2]]'', ''[[Voyager 1]]'' is now an [[interstellar probe]]. ''Voyager 1'' and ''2'' have both achieved solar [[escape velocity]], meaning that their trajectories will not return them to the Solar System.{{cite web |url=http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/fastfacts.html |title=Voyager-The Interstellar Mission: Fast Facts |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=November 2, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://voyager.jpl.nasa.gov/mission/interstellar.html |title=Voyager-The Interstellar Mission |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=November 2, 2013}} ==Probe imagers== Examples of space probe imaging telescope/cameras (focused on visible spectrum). {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%;" |- ! Name || [[Aperture]]
cm (in.) || [[Telescope|Type]] || Where || When |- | [[Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter]]{{mdash}}[[HiRISE]] || 50 cm (19.7″) || [[Ritchey–Chrétien|R/C]] || Mars orbit || 2005 |- |[[Mars Global Surveyor]]{{mdash}}MOC{{cite web|url=http://burro.astr.cwru.edu/stu/advanced/20th_far_mgs.html|title=Mars Global Surveyor|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120219064058/http://burro.astr.cwru.edu/stu/advanced/20th_far_mgs.html|archivedate=2012-02-19}} || 35 cm (13.8″) || [[Ritchey-Chrétien|R/C]] || Mars orbit || 1996–2006 |- | [[New Horizons]]{{mdash}}LORRI{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} || 20.8 cm (8.2″) || [[Ritchey–Chrétien|R/C]] || Space (33+ AU from Earth) || 2006 |- | [[Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter]] LROC-NAC{{cite web|url=http://events.eoportal.org/presentations/129/13466.html|title=eoportal – LRO (Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter) – LROC|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316204928/http://events.eoportal.org/presentations/129/13466.html|archivedate=2012-03-16}} || 19.5 cm (7.68″) || Reflector || Lunar orbit || 2009 |- | [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]{{mdash}}ISS-NAC{{cite web|url=http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/spacecraft/cassiniorbiterinstruments/instrumentscassiniiss/|title=Cassini Solstice Mission: ISS|work=Cassini Solstice Mission|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114074323/http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/spacecraft/cassiniorbiterinstruments/instrumentscassiniiss/|archivedate=2015-01-14}} || 19 cm (7.5″) || Reflector || Saturn orbit || 2004–2017 |- | [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]] – Solid State Imager{{cite web|url=http://www2.jpl.nasa.gov/basics/bsf12-1.php|title=Basics of Space Flight Section II. Space Flight Projects|work=nasa.gov}} || 17.65 cm (6.95″) || [[Cassegrain reflector|Reflector]] || Jupiter || 1989–2003 |- | [[Voyager 1]]/[[Voyager 2|2]], ISS-NAC{{cite web|url=http://www.astronautix.com/v/voyager.html|title=Voyager|work=astronautix.com}} || 17.6 cm (6.92″) || [[Catadioptric]] || Space || 1977 |- | [[Mariner 10]] – TV Photo Experiment (x2){{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=1973-085A-01|title=NASA – NSSDCA – Experiment – Details|publisher=}} || 15 cm (5.9″) || [[Cassegrain reflector|Reflector]] || Space || 1973–1975 |- |[[Deep Space 1]]{{mdash}}MICAS{{cite web|url=http://nmp.jpl.nasa.gov/ds1/|title=Deep Space 1|work=nasa.gov}} || 10 cm ( 3.94″) || Reflector || Solar orbit || 1998–2001 |- | [[Voyager 1]]/[[Voyager 2|2]], ISS-WAC || 6 cm (2.36″) || Lens || Space || 1977 |- | [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]{{mdash}}ISS-WAC || 5.7 cm (2.2″) || Lens || Saturn orbit || 2004–2017 |- | [[MESSENGER]] MDIS-WAC{{cite web|url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=2004-030A-01|title=NASA – NSSDCA – Experiment – Details|publisher=}} || 3 cm (1.18″) || [[Cooke triplet|Lens]] || Mercury orbit || 2004–2015 |- | [[MESSENGER]] MDIS-NAC{{cite web|url=http://starbrite.jpl.nasa.gov/pds/viewInstrumentProfile.jsp?INSTRUMENT_ID=MDIS-NAC&INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID=MESS|title=NASA PDS – MDIS|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602205942/http://starbrite.jpl.nasa.gov/pds/viewInstrumentProfile.jsp?INSTRUMENT_ID=MDIS-NAC&INSTRUMENT_HOST_ID=MESS|archivedate=2010-06-02}} || 2.5 cm (0.98″) || R/C || Mercury orbit || 2004–2015 |- | [[Dawn (spacecraft)|Dawn]] Framing Camera (FC1/FC2){{cite web|url=http://indico.cern.ch/getFile.py/access?contribId=19&resId=0&materialId=6&confId=43007|title=Sierks, et al. – The Dawn Framing Camera: A Telescope En Route to the Asteroid Belt – MPS/DLR/IDA|publisher=}} || 2 cm (0.8″) || Lens || Asteroid belt || 2007–2018 |} Image forming systems on space probes typically have a multitude of specifications, but aperture can be useful because it constrains the best [[diffraction limit]] and light gathering area.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} == Gallery == File:Voyager.jpg|Photograph of ''[[Voyager 1]]'' / ''[[Voyager 2]]'' File:Pioneer10-11.jpg|Artist's concept of ''[[Pioneer 10]]'' / ''[[Pioneer 11]]'' File:Pioneer 10 at Jupiter.gif|Artist's concept of ''[[Pioneer 10]]'' near [[Jupiter]] File:15-011a-NewHorizons-PlutoFlyby-ArtistConcept-14July2015-20150115.jpg|Artist's concept of ''New Horizons'' approaching [[Pluto]]. File:PIA19703-PlutoFlyby-NewHorizons-ArtistConcept-20150709.jpg|Artist's concept of ''[[New Horizons]]'' near [[Pluto]]. File:Cassini Saturn Orbit Insertion.jpg|Artist's concept of [[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]] in Saturn's orbit File:Galileo encounter with Io.png|Artist's concept of [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]] encounter with [[Io (moon)|Io]] File:Stardust20110323-full.jpg|Artist depiction of [[Stardust (spacecraft)|Stardust]] during the 'burn-to-depletion' phase File:Mars global surveyor.jpg|Artist depiction of [[Mars Global Surveyor]] File:Titan4B on Launch Complex 40.jpg| Titan4b on Launch pad ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight|Space}} {{cmn|colwidth=30em| * [[Interplanetary contamination]] * [[Interstellar probe]] * [[List of Solar System probes]] * [[Mariner 10]] 1973–1975 * [[Orbit]] * [[Pioneer 10]] 1972–2003 * [[Robotic spacecraft]] * [[Space capsule]] * [[Space exploration]] * [[Uncrewed spacecraft]] * [[U.S. space exploration history on U.S. stamps]] * [[Viking program]] 1975–1982 }} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == *''Deep Space: The NASA Mission Reports''. edited by Robert Godwin (2005). {{ISBN|1-894959-15-9}} ==Further reading== *[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/mcnuttstaif06.pdf McNutt, et al. – Radioisotope Electric Propulsion (2006) – NASA Glenn Research Center] (includes [[Centaur (minor planet)|Centaur]] orbiter mission) *[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/nov_2007_meeting/presentations/solar_power.pdf Scott W.
